text: ' ' This is mutiny ! ' ' said Tom bountifully .
s_p: in a bountiful manner
s_a: a ship of the British navy; in 1789 part of the crew mutinied against their commander William Bligh and set him afloat in an open boat
explanation: Poor Tom needs to be incorporated into better jokes. The word 'bountifully' does not refer to the way someone says something, which is why the joke fails.

text: When the plums dry on your tree, it ' s time to prune .
s_p: dried plum
s_a: cultivate, tend, and cut back the growth of
explanation: This is a pay on words. The word "prune" refers to the horticultural practice of pruning, or removing certain parts of a plant. However, a "prune" is also a type of dried plum.

text: If life gives you lemons, make lemonade .
Employers like their mechanics to be geared up .
s_p: make ready or suitable or equip in advance for a particular purpose or for some use, event, etc
s_a: a mechanism for transmitting motion for some specific purpose (as the steering gear of a vehicle)
explanation: The expression "geared up" means to be ready for the big game. Geared up also means having all the gear you need on. Mechanics fix machines which often require fixing the gears. Gears are a set of toothed wheels that work together in a machine. This pun is a play on the word gear.

text: A perfect woman is one that is inflated to 40 psi .
Actors are cast through their good and bad stages .
s_p: any distinct time period in a sequence of events
s_a: a large platform on which people can stand and can be seen by an audience
explanation: This sentence is a pun. It's saying that actors are cast through good and bad acting. The word used is stages instead of acting. A stage is a raised platform that actors act on.

text: She was only a Fireman ' s daughter, but she ' s really going to blazes .
s_p: a strong flame that burns brightly
s_a: a cause of difficulty and suffering
explanation: fire flame blazes when theres fire that needs to go out

text: The hardest thing for a person to keep is his opinion
s_p: cause to continue in a certain state, position, or activity; e.g., `keep clean'; retain possession of; continue a certain state, condition, or activity; stick to correctly or closely
s_a: prevent the action or expression of
explanation: The phrase "to give an opinion" means to share your thoughts on something. The joke is saying that people are often ready to give an opinion, and not all opinions are positive opinions.

text: ' ' This food tastes of plutonium, ' ' said Tom glowingly .
s_p: in an enthusiastically glowing manner
s_a: light from non-thermal sources; emit a steady even light without flames
explanation: This is a play on words. The word "glowingly" means spoken with enthusiastic praise but "glowingly" also refers to how plutonium is a radioactive element that glows or shines with a very bright light.

text: A big enough hammer can usually fix anything .
The passenger could not find where his next flight was, but then he made the connection .
s_p: the process of bringing ideas or events together in memory or imagination
s_a: shifting from one form of transportation to another
explanation: This is a pun on 'connection' which in the context of flying is a flight that requires passengers to change from one aircraft to another at a hub airport on the way to their final destination. But 'connection' is also used because the passenger is figured out what the problem was

text: Least said, soonest mended .
Did you hear about the farmer who got attacked by a cow ? He milked it for all it was worth .
s_p: take milk from female mammals
s_a: exploit as much as possible
c_w: milked it for all it was worth
explanation: The joke is a play on words.  Dairy cows on a farm are milked by farmers squeezing their udders into a bucket.  The phrase 'milked it for all it was worth' can typically be used to mean that someone who was injured or has some valid court charge against someone else abusing the power to get as much profit out of the court case as possible.

text: A friend cannot be known in prosperity nor an enemy be hidden in adversity .
' ' I have to sing a run of eighth notes, ' ' said Tom quaveringly .
s_p: in an unsteady quavering manner
s_a: a musical note having the time value of an eighth of a whole note
explanation: This is a play on words. The word "quaveringly" means to speak in a quivering voice but "quaver" is a term for an eighth of a note in music.

text: Why don ' t people like to talk to garbage men ? They mostly talk trash .
s_p: worthless material that is to be disposed of
s_a: nonsensical talk or writing
explanation: This is a pun on the term 'trash talk' which is to use insulting or boastful speech intended to demoralize, and it's also being used because garbage men deal with actual trash

text: ' ' Have you seen my collection of ancient Chinese artifacts ? ' ' asked Tom charmingly .
s_p: in a charming manner
s_a: the imperial dynasty of China from 1368 to 1644
explanation: This is a pun on the word "charmingly". "Charmingly" has the word "charm" in it. A charm can be an ancient Chinese artifact and the joke is about ancient Chinese artifacts.

text: Don’t let your footprints in the sands of time be the mark of a heel
s_p: the back part of the human foot; the bottom of a shoe or boot; the back part of a shoe or boot that touches the ground and provides elevation
s_a: someone who is morally reprehensible
explanation: heels are the back part of the foot

text: The sailor called his girlfriend ' s belly ring a naval destroyer .
s_p: connected with or belonging to or used in a navy
s_a: a scar where the umbilical cord was attached
explanation: A "naval destroyer" is a warship. "Naval" is a homophone of "navel". The navel is the place on a person's belly where the umbilical cord detached after birth. When the belly button gets pierced, the skin experiences trauma, maybe even gets a bit destroyed, and has to heal around the piercing. The sailor's girlfriend has a belly ring. This is where "navel destroyer" makes sense. This joke is playing on the term "naval destroyer" because it sounds like "navel destroyer".

text: The doctor couldn't transfer the organs because he didn't have the guts to do it .
s_p: fortitude and determination
s_a: the part of the alimentary canal between the stomach and the anus
explanation: This is a pun on 'guts' which in this context means personal courage and determination; toughness of character. But it's also being used because 'guts' is an informal term for organs

text: Doctor, doctor, I keep thinking I ' m a spoon . - Sit there and don ' t stir . Next .
s_p: move an implement through
s_a: move very slightly
explanation: Stir means move, or to mix thoroughly. Stir is a verb commonly used with spoons (so spoons stir, or mix drinks thoroughly for example). The person thinks they are a spoon. "Sit there and don't stir" means "sit there and don't move". This is a play on the word stir.

text: We Are Not Dairy Queen … But We Have Great Sundays
s_p: first day of the week; observed as a day of rest and worship by most Christians
s_a: ice cream served with a topping
explanation: "Sundays" is a homophone of "sundaes". Sundays is the plural of Sunday, which is a day in the week. Sundaes is the plural of sundae which is a type of dessert involving ice cream. A sundae typically has dairy as a main ingredient. A Dairy Queen is a fast food chain that serves ice cream. Tom is saying that they are not a Dairy Queen, but they have "great Sundays" meaning their Sundays are fun filled, but "great Sundays" sounds like "great sundaes", so "great ice cream". This joke is playing on the word Sundays and its homophone sundaes.

text: Scientists have created a flea from scratch .
s_p: from the beginning, especially without relying on resources or other advantages
s_a: scrape or rub as if to relieve itching
explanation: A flea is a type of jumping insect that feeds on the blood of mammals. A common symptom of someone who has fleas is itchiness, and scratching at itchiness is typical behavior. To scratch is to run one's fingernails over a skin surface to relieve itching. To "create something from scratch" is to make something with rudimentary ingredients, or from fundamentals. The flea was created from scratch. The joke is playing on the word "scratch" and its different meanings.

text: Food for bad dogs is bought by the pound .
s_p: 16 ounces avoirdupois
s_a: a public enclosure for stray or unlicensed dogs
explanation: A pound is a place where unwanted dogs are kept until they can be adopted by someone. A pound can refer to weight, so one pound of something is 0.45 kilograms of weight. Food can be bought by the pound. This pun is a play on the word pound.

text: Ne ' er cast a clout till May be out .
They won ' t stay at friendly hotels, because they ' re hostel people .
s_p: a hotel providing overnight lodging for travelers; inexpensive supervised lodging (especially for youths on bicycling trips)
s_a: characterized by enmity or ill will
explanation: A hotel is a building that travelers can temporarily stay in to sleep and get a meal. A hostel is a a lot like a hotel but cheaper. Hostel sounds like hostile. Hostile means unfriendly, or antagonistic.The joke is playing on the word "hostel" because it sounds like "hostile" and they won't stay at friendly hotels.

text: A baseball pitcher asked if he had a good curve ball, but wanted a straight answer .
s_p: free from curves or angles
s_a: characterized by honesty and fairness
explanation: The joke is a pun on the phrase 'straight answer'.  A straight answer means an honest answer with no spin or different take on it to change the meaning.  A curve ball is a ball that curves through the air as it is thrown.

text: If a dog was computer literate, would his bark be worse than his byte ?
s_p: a sequence of 8 bits (enough to represent one character of alphanumeric data) processed as a single unit of information
s_a: the act of gripping or chewing off with the teeth and jaws
explanation: This is a pun on 'bite' which is (of a person or animal) use the teeth to cut into or through something, but 'byte' is used in it's place because it sounds similar and refers to a group of binary digits or bits (usually eight) operated on as a unit which is related to computers

text: ' ' This movie will be very popular, ' ' Tom projected .
s_p: communicate vividly
s_a: project on a screen
explanation: This is a play on words. The word "projected" refers to Tom's manner of speaking but "projected" also refers to how movies are shown in theaters using projectors.

text: Actions speak louder than words .
Epitaphs are engraved !
s_p: carve, cut, or etch into a material or surface; carve or cut a design or letters into
s_a: a place for the burial of a corpse (especially beneath the ground and marked by a tombstone)
explanation: has to know what Epitaphs means

text: Many a true word is spoken in jest .
I used to have a life, now I have a modem .
For fast relief take two tablets . The ten commandments
s_p: a slab of stone or wood suitable for bearing an inscription
s_a: a dose of medicine in the form of a small pellet
explanation: The joke is a pun.  It sounds as if the speaker is talking about medication tablets, meaning pills, but the meaning of 'tablet' being used is the stone tablets that the ten commandments were chiseled on.

text: Justice delayed is justice denied .
No, baby oil does NOT come from squeezing dead babies .
I used to be afraid of purchasing residential property for the purpose of renting, but now I have an apartment complex .
s_p: a whole structure (as a building) made up of interconnected or related structures
s_a: (psychoanalysis) a combination of emotions and impulses that have been rejected from awareness but still influence a person's behavior
explanation: This is a pun on 'complex' which is this context is meaning a related group of emotionally significant ideas that are completely or partly repressed and that cause psychic conflict leading to abnormal mental states or behavior, but it's also being used because an alternative meaning of 'complex' is a group of similar buildings or facilities on the same site, like that of an apartment complex

text: ' ' I ' ve run out of wool, ' ' said Tom, knitting his brow .
s_p: make (textiles) by knitting
s_a: to gather something into small wrinkles or folds
explanation: This joke is a pun.  Wool is generally used for knitting.  However, to knit one's brow is to move the eyebrows together in a way that shows that one is thinking about something or is worried or angry.

text: A little pot is easily hot .
The swollen blood vessels in her legs were very quarrelsome - she had bellicose veins .
s_p: having or showing a ready disposition to fight
s_a: abnormally swollen or knotty
explanation: This is a play on words. The word "bellicose" means demonstrating aggression but sounds like "varicose" meaning a condition caused by the swelling of veins.

text: Fools rush in where angels fear to tread .
The astronomer became an actor because he always wanted to visit the stars .
s_p: (astronomy) a celestial body of hot gases that radiates energy derived from thermonuclear reactions in the interior
s_a: an actor who plays a principal role
explanation: A star is an actor who has a principal role in a movie or a show. Hollywood is full of actors that are stars. Stars can also refer to the luminous points seen in the night sky. Astronomers are people that observe and study objects outside of Earth, these include stars, planets, moons and comets. This joke is playing on the word "star" and its different meanings.

text: My dentist seems distracted, I think he was brushing me off .
s_p: clean with a brush
s_a: bar from attention or consideration
explanation: The joke is a pun.  'Brushing off' someone means to be disregarding them or ignoring them due to something else having their attention.  A dentist may 'brush' a patient's teeth with fluoride or some other teeth cleaner.

text: One rotten apple will spoil the whole barrel .
In parking lots, arguments often start from scratch .
s_p: from the beginning, especially without relying on resources or other advantages
s_a: a depression scratched or carved into a surface
explanation: from scratch' means 'from the beginning of a process using only raw materials', and is also a pun on a scratch made in car metal.

text: The man who fell into an upholstery machine is fully recovered .
s_p: get over an illness or shock
s_a: cover anew
explanation: This is a pun on 'recovered' which means to return to a normal state of health, mind, or strength,  like you'd want to recover after falling into a machine. But it's also being used because upholstery is the work of providing furniture, especially seats, with padding, springs, webbing, and fabric or leather covers. So in this case the speaker was covered in fabric

text: Fear not the loss of the bell more than the loss of the steeple .
I met a man who loves eating couches . I think he has a suite tooth .
s_p: a matching set of furniture
s_a: having or denoting the characteristic taste of sugar
explanation: A suite is a set of rooms that contain furniture. A couch is a piece of furniture that multiple people can sit on. Suite and sweet are homophones. Sweet is a descriptive word used to describe the taste of something, typically if that something is sugary. If someone has a "sweet tooth" it means they really like and crave eating sweet things. The joke is centered around the word suite and its homophone sweet.

text: Is that pure rump roast ? Nothing butt .
s_p: the fleshy part of the human body that you sit on
s_a: and nothing more
explanation: This is a joke on the fact that rump roasts come from the butt of the animal, and the speaker answering the question here is confirming that the product is nothing butt pure rump roast roast

text: The more the merrier .
I trained my dog to hunt for underground mushrooms but now he ' s more truffle than he ' s worth .
s_p: edible subterranean fungus of the genus Tuber; any of various highly prized edible subterranean fungi of the genus Tuber; grow naturally in southwestern Europe
s_a: a source of difficulty
explanation: Pun on the similarity between "truffle" and "trouble". Truffles are a rare underground mushroom considered a delicacy, and dogs are commonly trained to search for them in the right environments.

text: The other day I held the door open for a clown . I thought it was a nice jester .
s_p: a professional clown employed to entertain a king or nobleman in the Middle Ages
s_a: something done as an indication of intention
explanation: This is a pun on 'jester', which is type of clown in a medieval court, but it's also used because it sounds similar to 'gesture' which is an action performed to convey one's feelings or intentions, like holding the door open for someone

text: The phone call interrupted my nap, and I never did get the rest .
s_p: something left after other parts have been taken away
s_a: a pause for relaxation
explanation: Rest can mean a break from something, but it can also mean a part of something. "The rest" of something is the last part of something. "Never did get the rest" can mean "I never did get a break" or "I never did get the last part of something". This joke is playing on the word "rest" and its different meanings.

text: ' ' I can tell which way the wind blows, ' ' said Tom vainly .
s_p: to no avail
s_a: mechanical device attached to an elevated structure; rotates freely to show the direction of the wind
explanation: The joke is a pun. To do something 'vainly' is to do it with an excessively high opinion of one's appearance, abilities, or worth.  A 'weather vane' is a device typically on roofs of buildings that turns to show the direction of the wind.

text: Piano players know what bar they are in .
s_p: a room or establishment where alcoholic drinks are served over a counter
s_a: musical notation for a repeating pattern of musical beats
explanation: This is a play on words. A "bar" is a drinking establishment where musicians or performers sometimes play. However, a "bar" is also a segment of time corresponding to a specific number of beats in music.

text: Vines are extremely short - tempered . They snap at the slightest wind .
s_p: separate or cause to separate abruptly
s_a: utter in an angry, sharp, or abrupt tone
explanation: To be short-tempered is to be someone that gets easily angered. To snap at something means to quickly take an angry tone with someone. To snap can also mean to break suddenly. The word snap fits the vine in both ways. The vine is personified as being short-tempered, but it can also be physically snapped, or broken by the wind. This joke is a play on the word snap and its different meanings.

text: " Tea, Early Grey, hot " - Picard . . " Ale, Romulan, lots . " - Kirk
Vegetarian : Indian word for lousy hunter ! ! !
I before E except after C, huh ? Weird . . . . .
I finished my trigonometry exam without a secant to lose .
s_p: a straight line that intersects a curve at two or more points
s_a: 1/60 of a minute; the basic unit of time adopted under the System International d'Unites; an indefinitely short time
explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'without a second to lose' meaning you completed a task using every minute of the allotted time. However, 'secant' is used in place of 'second' because it sounds similar and because 'secant' refers to the ratio of the hypotenuse to the shorter side adjacent to an acute angle (in a right-angled triangle); the reciprocal of a cosine, which I'm guessing is related to trigonometry (I never took it)

text: He was trying to sell me new windows, but his motivations were transparent .
s_p: transmitting light; able to be seen through with clarity
s_a: easily understood or seen through (because of a lack of subtlety)
explanation: This is a pun on 'transparent' which in this context mean easy to perceive or detect, but 'transparent' can also mean allowing light to pass through so that objects behind can be distinctly seen, which is what windows literally are

text: Did you hear about the bivalve they called in to interrogate for that big murder investigation ? Apparently, he ' s clammed up .
s_p: refuse to talk or stop talking; fall silent
s_a: burrowing marine mollusk living on sand or mud; the shell closes with viselike firmness
explanation: This is a pun on 'clammed up' which means to become silent, and it's also being used because bivalve's are a type of mollusk, aka clam

text: A goat that ate office supplies was on a staple diet .
s_p: necessary or important, especially regarding food or commodities
s_a: paper fastener consisting of a short length of U-shaped wire that can fasten papers together
explanation: A staple diet refers to a diet that consists of foods eaten regularly. A staple can refer to a piece of thin wire driven by a stapler through sheets of paper to fasten them together. The joke is referencing a goat that is eating office supplies, so consuming a "staple diet" could mean consuming a diet high in staples (thin metal wires) or a diet high in regular foods.

text: Don ' t confuse me with facts, my mind is made up !
Precepts teach, examples move .
A skier who loses a race on a cold day will have a frosty disposition .
s_p: devoid of warmth and cordiality; expressive of unfriendliness or disdain
s_a: covered with frost; ; -Wm.Faulkner
explanation: "Frosty disposition" can mean someone who is being unfriendly, or emotionally cold. Frosty is an adjective that can also refer to the temperature being cold. Frosty was cleverly chosen as an adjective to refer to a skier's disposition and to describe a cold day.

text: If the theists all shut up, the gods would be speechless .
Success is a journey not a destination .
Marry in haste, and repent at leisure .
I used to do rock climbing as a youth, but I was much boulder back then .
s_p: a large smooth mass of rock detached from its place of origin
s_a: fearless and daring
explanation: Boulder sounds like bolder. Bolder means courageous, one who will willingly take risks. A boulder can refer to a giant rock. This joke is playing on the word "boulder" because it sounds like "bolder".

text: Overheard in med school - ' I learned about the colon through the process of elimination . '
s_p: the bodily process of discharging waste matter
s_a: analysis of a problem into alternative possibilities followed by the systematic rejection of unacceptable alternatives
explanation: This is a pun on "process of elimination". Process of elimination is when you find the answer through eliminating answers that you know aren't true in order to find the true answer. Process of elimination can also be interpreted as a colon getting rid of human waste.

text: A good carpenter will do his work and then varnish without a trace .
s_p: cover with varnish
s_a: get lost, as without warning or explanation
explanation: Varnish is a liquid that becomes a hard, transparent finish when dried often applied to wooden furniture after construction by a carpenter. Varnish also sounds like vanish, which is to disappear out of sight, and plays on the phrase vanish without a trace.

text: When the human cannonball retired they couldn't find a replacement of the right caliber .
s_p: a degree or grade of excellence or worth
s_a: diameter of a tube or gun barrel
explanation: The joke is a pun. A human cannonball is a person who performs an act in a circus or similar show by getting fired out of a cannon. Finding someone of 'the right caliber' means finding someone who has the proper quality or level of ability. 'Caliber' also means the internal diameter or bore of a gun barrel.

text: My friends call me Mesa because of my big butte .
s_p: a hill that rises abruptly from the surrounding region; has a flat top and sloping sides
s_a: the fleshy part of the human body that you sit on
explanation: This is a play on words. A butte is an isolated hill similar to a mesa. However, "butte" also sounds like "butt" which refers to the rear end of the body.

text: For a dishonest employee : He ' s an unbelievable worker .
s_p: having a probability too low to inspire belief
s_a: beyond belief or understanding
explanation: The joke is a pun. Being 'an unbelievable worker' typically means being very good at one's job.  Being a dishonest person would make it hard for people to believe what that person is saying.  The person in this joke is probably so dishonest that they are called 'unbelievable' or unable to be believed or trusted.

text: Inflammatory talk is often seen as propane language .
s_p: colorless gas found in natural gas and petroleum; used as a fuel
s_a: characterized by profanity or cursing
explanation: This is a play on the word "inflammatory," usually meaning violent, but here it also is made to sound like "inflammable," while "propane," which sounds like 'profane," is also inflammable

text: Old electricians never die, they just get discharged .
s_p: having lost your job
s_a: remove the charge from
explanation: Discharged means to be released from obligation. An electrician is someone that installs or maintains electrical equipment. Electric discharge is the release and movement of electricity through a medium. This joke is playing on the word "discharge" and its different meanings.

text: When the head is sick, the whole body is sick .
When it was lumpy he had a beef with his gravy .
s_p: informal terms for objecting
s_a: meat from an adult domestic bovine
explanation: This is a pun on the word "beef". "Beef" is meat from cows that can be made into gravy or eaten with gravy poured on top. The phrase "have beef" is an idiom that means to be angry or annoyed at someone or something. The gravy still had lumps of beef in it. The person was bothered by the gravy's lumpiness so he "had beef" with it.

text: An architect knows how to make a long storey short .
s_p: a structure consisting of a room or set of rooms at a single position along a vertical scale
s_a: a message that tells the particulars of an act or occurrence or course of events; presented in writing or drama or cinema or as a radio or television program; a record or narrative description of past events
explanation: This is a pun on 'make a long story short' which is used to indicate that you are providing just the basic facts rather than giving a lengthy explanation for something. However, 'storey' is used in place of 'story' because it sounds identically similar and because 'storey' refers to a part of a building comprising all the rooms that are on the same level, which is what architectures deal with

text: Dentist ' s famous last words : " You won ' t feel a thing . . . "
On cooking shows, there is little margarine of error .
s_p: a spread made chiefly from vegetable oils and used as a substitute for butter
s_a: a permissible difference; allowing some freedom to move within limits
explanation: This is a pun on 'margine of error' which is a statistic expressing the amount of random sampling error in the results of a survey, but 'margarine' is used in it's place because it sounds somewhat similar and because 'margarine' is a spread used for flavoring, baking and cooking

text: Copper wire was invented by lawyers arguing over a penny .
An idea is not responsible for fools who believe in it .
When those around King Arthur ' s table had insomnia, there were a lot of sleepless knights .
s_p: originally a person of noble birth trained to arms and chivalry; today in Great Britain a person honored by the sovereign for personal merit
s_a: the period spent sleeping
explanation: Sleepless knights means that the knights with insomnia were not sleeping. "Sleepless knights" sounds like "sleepless nights" which is a term often used to express not sleeping at night. The joke is playing on the word "knights" because it sounds like "nights".

text: A civil question deserves a civil answer .
When she made Mario Puzo ' s books required reading for her class, she made him an author they couldn ' t refuse .
s_p: writes (books or stories or articles or the like) professionally (for pay)
s_a: something offered (as a proposal or bid); the verbal act of offering
explanation: Wordplay. Mario Puzo is the author of the novel that the famous film The Godfather is adapted from. A famous line from the movie involves one character saying that they will intimidate another into following their orders by "making him an offer he can't refuse". The pun is on the similarity in sound between "offer" and "author"; the students cannot refuse to read Puzo's works because he is required reading for the class.

text: Better underdone than overdone .
Diplomacy : Saying " Nice doggie " until you can find a rock
Herb gardeners who work extra get thyme and a half .
s_p: any of various mints of the genus Thymus
s_a: a period of time considered as a resource under your control and sufficient to accomplish something
explanation: The joke is a pun. A gardener growing herbs may grow the herb, 'thyme'.  The phrase 'time and a half' means receiving fifty percent extra pay for working, typically on holidays.  Thyme and time sound identical.

text: Hire teenagers while they still know everything .
Why are all businessmen fat ? Must be all the inflation .
s_p: a general and progressive increase in prices
s_a: the act of filling something with air
explanation: This is a play on words. "Inflation" refers to a general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing power of money. However, "inflation" also means a general increase in the size of something, like a balloon, implying that inflation is causing businessmen to become inflated or fat.

text: Husbands are like fires . They go out when unattended .
s_p: become extinguished
s_a: leave the house to go somewhere
explanation: This is a play on words. A fire "going out" when unattended means the fire stops burning if you stop giving it kindling. A husband "going out" when unattended means the husband will "go out" or leave if he's not receiving attention.

text: Modern fashion designs are often presented with tongue in chic .
s_p: elegance by virtue of being fashionable
s_a: either side of the face below the eyes
explanation: Chic is a word to describe something as fashionable or elegant. Tongue in cheek is a common phrase used to describe something that is insincere.

text: Burn not your house to rid it of the mouse .
One of these new shoes isn ' t right .
s_p: being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north
s_a: in or into a satisfactory condition
explanation: A pair of shoes will contain a shoe for a left foot and right foot. If something is "not right" it can often mean that something is not correct. This joke is taking the dual meaning of someone feeling like the shoes are somehow not correct, or it can be interpreted as one of the shoes being for a left foot.

text: Bike sales go in cycles .
s_p: a wheeled vehicle that has two wheels and is moved by foot pedals
s_a: an interval during which a recurring sequence of events occurs
explanation: This is a pun on 'go in cycles' which means a course or series of events or operations that recur regularly and usually lead back to the starting point, but it's also being used because the official word for bike is bicycle

text: She was only a Swimmer ' s daughter, but she knew every dive in town . .
s_p: a cheap disreputable nightclub or dance hall
s_a: a headlong plunge into water
explanation: This is a pun on 'dive' which in this context is referring to a shabby or sleazy bar or similar establishment. It's also being used since swimmers dive into pools

text: Business at the candle factory tapered off after the holidays .
s_p: become smaller or less active
s_a: a loosely woven cord (in a candle or oil lamp) that draws fuel by capillary action up into the flame

text: On TV it ' s a maze of channels, luckily he had a guide .

s_a: something that offers basic information or instruction
explanation: This is a play on words. A "guide" refers to someone who can help in navigating through the maze of TV channels but a TV "guide" is a magazine or website that tells what's on television at different times of the day.

text: OLD DOOR FRAMERS never die, they just become unhinged .

explanation: Doors have hinges. Hinges are a movable joint which a door swings on. Sometimes with repeated use and age, a door can become unhinged and will need to be fixed. To "become unhinged" can also refer to a mentally unbalanced, or deranged human being. The joke is referring to old door framers, and is playing on the word "unhinged".

text: Someone who attempts long distance fraud is known as a phony .

s_a: electronic equipment that converts sound into electrical signals that can be transmitted over distances and then converts received signals back into sounds
explanation: Long distance fraud can occur on the phone. Scammers that live far away from the people they are scamming will make a phone call to a victim, lie, then ask for money. "Phony" means fraudulent, but can also replace the suffix "-phone" which relates to sound. "Phone" is not only a suffix, but a communication device that allows for long distance communication. The joke is playing on the word phony, how it sounds close to 'phone' and long distance fraud.

text: An Electrician ' s work is well grounded .

explanation: The joke is in the use of the phrase 'well grounded' which means secure. In working with electricity, a ground line is a wire that connects to the ground to give a path for the electricity to travel and prevent short circuits and accidental shocks. An electrician would probably always try to be 'well grounded'

text: Tony attempted to join his thin crust pizza company with Zimo ' s Thick Crust Pizza, but somehow it didn ' t pan out .

explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'didn't pan out' which means something didn't turn out the expected way, but it's also being used because sometimes you bake pizzas in a pan

text: A scientist who wanted a tattoo got a skin graph .

explanation: A skin graft is a patch of skin that is removed by surgery from one area of the body and is attached to another area. "Skin graft" sounds like "skin graph". A tattoo is a type of skin modification involving ink. A graph is a diagram showing the relation between variable quantities, typically of two variables. Scientists often use or analyze graphs to understand trends. This pun is playing on the word "graph" because it sounds like "graft" as in "skin graft" while referring to a scientist wanting a tattoo.

text: Doctor, Doctor, this ointment you gave me makes my arm smart . . - Then rub some on your head ? Next .

text: Elephants will toil all day, and they work for peanuts .

explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'work for peanuts' which means to work for very little compensation. But it's being used here because elephants famously eat peanuts

text: I wanted to do some research on anorexia, so I went to the library to get the skinny .

explanation: The joke is a pun. The phrase 'get the skinny' means to 'gather information' or 'get a summary'.  'Skinny' also means having very little body weight, which might happen if one was anorexic and avoiding eating.

text: Two florists got married . It was an arranged marriage .

text: When the proposal was made to locate the governor ' s mansion in Albany, New Yorkers said, ' ' That ' s a capitol idea . ' '

text: Lizards have a very strong heartbeat which can be faintly heard anywhere on their body, said Mr . Johnson, beginning a story . ' ' Come listen to this tail . ' '
s_p: the posterior part of the body of a vertebrate especially when elongated and extending beyond the trunk or main part of the body
s_a: a message that tells the particulars of an act or occurrence or course of events; presented in writing or drama or cinema or as a radio or television program
explanation: The joke is in the use of the word tail. A tale is another word for a story, but since they are talking about lizards, it is literally about the tail body part of a lizard. 'Come listen to this tail' sounds like the speaker is beginning to tell a long story, but they literally mean that you can hear the heartbeat of the lizard through its tail.

text: Justice pleaseth few in their own house .

text: The teacher asked a question and the students were all up in arms .

text: Are evil wildebeests bad gnus ?

s_a: informal information of any kind that is not previously known to someone
explanation: This is a pun on the word "gnus" Gnus are wildebeests. "gnus" sounds like "news". The evil wildebeests are bad news because they are bad gnus.

text: An old professor who was never on time died and was called the late professor Brown .

explanation: This is a pun on "late". They were called the late professor Brown because of their tardiness as well as the fact that they were dead. You use the word "late" to refer to a deceased person.

text: The weather man said there won ' t be any rain for 6 months, but I drought it .
s_p: a shortage of rainfall

explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'doubt it' which means a feeling of uncertainty or lack of conviction, but 'drought' is used in it's place because it kind of sounds similar and because a drought is what happens when it rains infrequently

text: My friend gave me a book about puns for my birthday and I loved it . It was two meaningful .

text: A bellyful is one of meat, drink, or sorrow .

Concrete is a mixture of aggregates. The joke is saying that you should seal in your mind the correct formula for concrete.

text: Darwin said he ' d have to see what evolved .
s_p: work out

explanation: See what evolved is a colloquialism for waiting for a situation to play out. Charles Darwin was a scientist known for his contributions to evolutionary biology.

text: The guitarist passed out on stage, he must have rocked himself to sleep .

text: A china doll was marked in tiny letters : ' maid in USA ' .

text: ' ' Who discovered radium ? ' ' asked Tom curiously .

text: OLD VIOLINISTS never die, they just become unstrung .

text: Gardeners like to spring into action .

text: You don ' t get nothing for nothing .

text: She swallowed a peach seed and could feel it in the pit of her stomach .

The person in this joke swallowed a peach seed and felt anxiety. text: The pun in the title of the play ' ' The Importance of Being Earnest ' ' was a Wilde idea .

explanation: The joke is a pun.  To say something has a 'nice ring to it' means that it sounds nice.  'Ring' could also mean the wedding ring, which may in fact be a nice ring.

text: The snowstorm arrived at a fortuitous moment . It was white on time .
s_p: being of the achromatic color of maximum lightness; having little or no hue owing to reflection of almost all incident light; marked by the presence of snow
s_a: precisely, exactly; exactly
explanation: "White on time" sounds like "right on time" which is a common phrase. Snow is white. The joke is using the word white to replace the word "right" because "white" references the color of snow.

text: I ' m not worthless . I can always serve as a bad example .
Without temptation there is no victory .
What are you taking pictures of ? Tom snapped .
s_p: utter in an angry, sharp, or abrupt tone
s_a: record on photographic film
explanation: "Snapped" can mean angrily. Snapped can also be the past tense of the verb "snap" which is the verb used to explain what people do when the take pictures. They snap pictures. Tom "snapped" at someone who is taking pictures. This joke is playing on the different meanings of the word snapped.

text: There is nothing new under the sun .

explanation: Compliment is used mean to give praise to, the task of sycophants. Compliment also sounds like complement, which is to bring to a full set, in this case the ships personnel.

text: An alien landed at a soft drink company and said ' take me to your liter ' .

explanation: This is a pun on the phrase 'take me to your leader' which is used in pop culture whenever alien lifeforms wish to speak with leaders of earth, but 'liter' is used here because it sounds similar and because 'liter' is a common liquid measurement form that soft drinks come in

I fought with Geronimo, said Tom bravely .

text: Epitaph on a gravestone : Cheerio, see you soon .

explanation: sound business practices' normally means having practices that can hold up against scrutiny and predictable changes. Here though it's also a reference to the sound that music makes.

text: Multitasking = screwing up several things at once .
The store clerk lost his job, so he set up a kiosk in the mall to vend for himself .
s_p: sell or offer for sale from place to place
s_a: try to manage without help
explanation: "Fend for himself" means to do things without help. The store clerk lost his job. "Vend" sounds close to "fend". Vend is used to replace fend because a kiosk can be a vending machine. This joke is playing on the word "vend".

text: A course offered to introduce French in five easy liaisons .
s_p: a usually secretive or illicit sexual relationship
s_a: a unit of instruction
explanation: I think liaisons is supposed to sound like "lessons". In French a liaison is the pronunciation of a linking consonant between two words. Lessons refer to something learned or taught. This joke is playing on the word "liaisons" because it sounds like "lessons".

text: Beggars can ' t be choosers .
When the human cannonball was late for work he got fired .
s_p: terminate the employment of; discharge from an office or position
s_a: cause to go off
explanation: To be fired at a job means the employer terminates employment against the will of the worker. Showing up late for work multiple times can be enough to get fired. To fire a cannon means to set it off. The use of the word "fire" is used in two ways here.

text: The decision to begin construction on the Empire State Building was a groundbreaking historical event .
s_p: being or producing something like nothing done or experienced or created before
s_a: the ceremonial breaking of the ground to formally begin a construction project
explanation: I think the joke is a pun.  'Groundbreaking' can mean something that is the first of its kind, or a remarkable step in progress.  To start constructing a building, a foundation needs to be built by 'breaking' the ground.

explanation: This is a pun on 'played out' which usually means when you hear a song/ artist too much and you lose interest in them.

text: If you say you have bad skin, I ' d say that was a pore excuse .
s_p: any small opening in the skin or outer surface of an animal
s_a: lacking in quality or substances
explanation: The joke is a pun. A 'pore' is a pocket in the skin where oils are let out. 'Pore' sounds like 'poor' which would make the phrase 'poor excuse', meaning that it is not a valid reason.

text: OLD WRITERS never die, they just get erased .
s_p: remove from memory or existence
s_a: remove by or as if by rubbing or erasing
explanation: This is a pun on 'erased' which means rub out or remove (writing or marks), like writers do, but it also means remove all traces of (a thought, feeling, or memory), which is akin to death

text: OLD PROFESSORS never die, they just lose their class .
s_p: a body of students who are taught together
s_a: elegance in dress or behavior
explanation: A professor is a type of teacher that teaches at a university. To lose class means to act in a way without grace, poise, or maturity. To lose a class can also mean to lose the ability to teach a class. Class also has the definition of being a time period when a teacher teaches a group of students together. This joke is playing on the word class and its different meanings.

text: Do not merely believe in miracles, rely on them .
A bird with a headache might just migraine south .
s_p: a severe recurring vascular headache; occurs more frequently in women than men
s_a: move periodically or seasonally
explanation: Migraine is a type of painful headache. Migraine sounds like migrate, which is the act of birds flying to warmer areas during cold weather.  The bird has a headache, so it migraines south.

text: Scientists studying the sun have a flare for research .
s_p: a sudden eruption of intense high-energy radiation from the sun's surface; associated with sunspots and radio interference
s_a: a natural talent
explanation: A solar flare is term used to describe an explosion on the sun. Flare is a homophone of flair. Flair means to have an inclination or tendency towards something. The scientists in this joke have an inclination for research, and the word "flare" is used because its a homophone of "flair" and the scientists are studying explosions on the sun, or solar flares.

text: Doctor, Doctor, you ' ve got to help me . I think I ' m a kleptomaniac . - Don ' t worry . I think there ' s something you can take for that . Next .
s_p: get into one's hands, take physically
s_a: serve oneself to, or consume regularly
explanation:
A kleptomaniac is someone that has an impulse control disorder with an irresistible urge to steal. 
The part where the doctor says "something you can take for that" can refer to consuming something, like a medication, to treat someone for something. The joke is in the doctor telling the kleptomaniac that that there's something that person "can take" as kleptomaniacs keep taking.
